Award.AwardTitle: A Study of the Tidal Modulation of Ice-shelf Flow using a Viscoelastic Model of the Ross Ice Shelf
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a two-year study of the flow of the Ross Ice Shelf, Antarctica, which is the portion of the Antarctic ice sheet that is floating on the Ross Sea. The Ross Ice Shelf (along with the Filchner-Ronne Ice Shelf) provides an important, stabilizing back-pressure on the seaward flow of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, which is the portion of the Antarctic ice sheet that is most at risk of catastrophic disintegration.

The study aims to understand the interaction between the Ross Ice Shelf and the ocean by developing a map-plane two-dimensional, viscoelastic, ice-flow model. This model will explore the tidal modulation of mean, time-averaged ice-shelf flow velocity. The model will then be assessed based on GPS measurements that have previously been collected in the field, at a site near the center of the seaward, iceberg-calving front of the ice shelf. The results of this ice-dynamics study will contribute significantly to the ice-sheet modeling community by: 1) providing an independent assessment of both the viscous and elastic components of the ice-shelf response to the ocean tide; 2) providing a better understanding of the sensitivities of the coupled ocean/ice-shelf system; and 3) incorporating both viscous and elastic elements into an integrated ocean/ice-shelf/ice-stream system that addresses tidal modulation of the flow of glacial ice across the grounding line. Having an increased understanding of the ice-shelf-flow dynamics, and an understanding of the teleconnection between the ice shelves and the ice sheets via the ice streams, will assist ice-sheet modelers to better understand the evolution of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, which is currently the largest Antarctic contribution to mean-sea-level rise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice shelves play an important role in the coupled ice-sheet/ocean system by regulating the flow of grounded ice from the Antarctic Ice Sheet into the Southern Ocean. Reasonable models exist of the time-averaged motions of ice shelves on long timescales (months to years), where ice behaves in a viscous fashion. However, we still have difficulties modeling the motions observed in ice shelves at shorter timescales (days to weeks), where the system demonstrates elastic responses to forcings at similar frequencies, such as ocean tides. This research developed a finely resolved model of the viscous component of motion and developed a relatively coarser model of the visco-elastic component of the motion.

The finely resolved viscous component of the model was developed in software called Matlab and captures the long-period time-averaged flow of Ross Ice Shelf based on comparisons with satellite-based velocity data and comparisons with ground-based GPS data collected at the ice-shelf front. The high quality of the modeling result stems in part from incorporating the most state-of-the-art datasets into the model, including: 1) a detailed model boundary from NASA satellite data (ICESat); 2) ice-shelf thickness information based on the hydrostatic inversion of NASA satellite data (ICESat); 3) corrections to ice-shelf thickness based on NASA airborne data (MCoRDS, an Operation IceBridge radar sounder); and 4) initial velocities on the model boundary from a recent NASA MEaSUREs project (continent-scale InSAR-based ice velocity from various satellite datasets). Similar high-quality results were obtained when applying this model to the Getz Ice Shelf, where aircraft data, so critical to correcting ice-shelf thickness, also exist.

The coarser visco-elastic component of the Ross Ice Shelf model was developed in software called Comsol. While the original intent was to develop this component in parallel to the viscous component, Matlab is limited with respect to the treatment of partial differential equations. Thus, the visco-elastic modeling effort was migrated to Comsol Multiphysics, which is better suited to this type of math. While the visco-elastic equations were solved in Comsol, incorporating the high-resolution, state-of-the-art geophysical datasets has been difficult. Thus, the visco-elastic model only captures the relative sensitivities of the tidal forcings on the ice shelf, such as initial ice-flow velocity along the model boundary and tidal parameters.

Results of these modeling efforts have been presented at two international meetings: the Forum for Research into Ice Shelf Processes and the International Glaciological Society Symposium on Interactions of Ice Sheets and Glaciers with the Ocean.
